F.

Implementation Arrangements

1. 

Project Implementation

67.
Barki  Tajik,  which  has  managed  several  small  power  projects  will  be  the  Executing
Agency for the Project and will be responsible for its overall execution and management.  Barki
Tajik will also enter into a project agreement with ADB to confirm it will use the loan proceeds
for  the  Project  and  comply  with  all  relevant  provisions  of  the  loan  agreement.  Project
implementation  will  be  coordinated  with  the  local  United  Nations  (UN)  office  to  ensure  safe
working conditions. A project implementation unit (PIU) was set up in June 2000 to undertake
coordination,  reporting,  procurement,  and  disbursement  for  all  project  components  except  for
part  E  (c).  The  PIU  is  headed  by  a  project  manager,  appointed  by  Barki  Tajik  and  having
qualifications  acceptable  to  ADB.    Project  implementation  consultants  will  assist  the  PIU  in
project management, social and environmental matters, procurement, construction supervision,
and  training  activities.  All  project  components  are  scheduled  to  be  completed  by  December
2005 (Appendix 5).

68.
For  the  rehabilitation  of  CHPP  (part  A)  and  NHPP  (part  B),  the  major  activities  are
(i) detailed planning and preparation of bidding documents, during the first six months of 2001;
(ii) invitation to bid within a period of three months from July 2001; (iii) contract awards at the
end of 2001; and (iv) completion of construction within two and a half years from January 2002.
The  longer  schedule  for  rehabilitation  of  the  transmission  and  distribution  system  in  Khatlon
Region is based on the complexity of works involved and similar experience in other transition
economies. For this component, the invitation to bid will be issued by mid-2001, the contract will
be awarded by the end of 2001, and commissioning will take place almost four years thereafter.
Part C is expected to be completed within three years and Part D within two and half years from
January 2002. For part E, shortlisting of project implementation consultants is to be completed
by the end of 2000 and the selection of consultants will take three months from January 2001.
Consulting services for implementation will be provided until the end of the Project in late 2005.
For auditing Barki Tajik and implementing Energy Law regulations, consultants will be recruited
by mid-2001 and services provided from 2001 to 2002. MOE will be the Implementing Agency
responsible for the selection and supervision of the consultants for the Energy Law regulations.

2.

Procurement

69.
All  goods  and  services  financed  by  the  ADB  loan  will  be  procured  in  accordance  with
ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. Contract packages financed by cofinanciers will be procured
using their procedures. The procurement packages for transmission and distribution equipment
and materials have been optimized to facilitate procurement administration, and to make such
packages  attractive  for  international  competitive  bidding  (Appendix  6).  All  ADB-financed  civil
works contracts estimated to cost the equivalent of more than $1 million and all supply contracts
estimated  to  cost  the  equivalent  of  more  than  $500,000  will  be  awarded  on  the  basis  of
international  competitive  bidding.  Civil  works  contracts  estimated  to  cost  the  equivalent  of
$1 million or less and supply contracts estimated to cost the equivalent of $500,000 or less will

 20

be awarded on the basis of international shopping. The project implementation consultants will
prescribe  the  functional  design,  and  the  contractor  will  be  responsible  for  detailed  design  of
plant and equipment on the basis of a two-stage bidding approach. The civil works at the NHPP
switchyard  foundations  financed  by  Barki  Tajik  will  comprise  a  package  suitable  for  local
competitive  bidding,  for  which  Barki  Tajik  will  use  ADB's  standard  bidding  documents.  Barki
Tajik will maintain transparency and accountability as required under ADB's anticorruption policy
in undertaking procurement of goods and services.

3. 

Consulting Services

70.
Consulting  services  will  be  required  for  implementing  parts  A  to  D.  Approximately  106
person-months of international and 110 person-months of domestic consultants will be needed
(Supplementary  Appendix  D).  Consulting  services  will  also  be  provided  to  audit  Barki  Tajik’s
corporate  and  project  accounts  for  fiscal  years  2000  and  2001.  The  auditing  will  be  in
accordance with IAS and the consultants will make recommendations for improving Barki Tajik's
financial management. This will require about 6 person-months of international and 15 person-
months  of  domestic  consultants  (Supplementary  Appendix  E).  In  addition,  consulting  services
will  be  provided  to  help  the  Government  develop  charters  and  regulations  to  implement  the
Energy Law. This will require about 17 person-months of international and 7 person-months of
domestic  consulting  services  (Supplementary  Appendix  F).  All  consultants  will  be  recruited  by
the Government and Barki Tajik in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants
and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB on the engagement of domestic consultants. The
Government  has  requested  that  the  internationally-recruited  consultants  shall  collaborate  with
the domestic consultants. ADB has agreed to this request and specific arrangements relating to
the collaboration will be included in the consultants' proposals.

4.

Disbursement

The  Government  and  Barki  Tajik  will  adopt  either  of  the  following  disbursement
71.
procedures for withdrawing proceeds of the loan in accordance with ADB’s Loan Disbursement
Handbook:  (i)  a  direct  payment  procedure,  where  ADB  at  the  request  of  the  Government  will
pay a designated beneficiary directly; or (ii) a commitment procedure, where ADB at the request
of  the  Government,  will  reimburse  a  commercial  bank  for  payments  made  or  to  be  made  to  a
supplier against a letter of credit financed from the loan account.

5. 

Reports, Accounts, and Audit

72.
There will be continued monitoring and evaluation of project implementation, with timely
reporting.  Barki  Tajik  will  prepare  quarterly  reports  on  progress  of  project  implementation  and
furnish  ADB  and  cofinanciers  with  copies  of  these  reports.  ADB  will  review  implementation  of
the  Project  on  a  regular  basis,  at  least  once  a  year,  and  will  monitor  overall  performance  of
Barki Tajik. Within three months of completion of the Project, Barki Tajik will furnish ADB with a
project  completion  report  covering  details  of  implementation  and  other  information  required  by
ADB. Barki Tajik will maintain separate records and accounts for the Project and will have the
accounts  audited  annually  by  independent  auditors  acceptable  to  ADB.  Copies  of  audited
project accounts will be provided to ADB within nine months after the end of each relevant fiscal
year.  Barki  Tajik  will  also  provide  ADB  with  copies  of  its  audited  corporate  accounts  within  12
months of the end of its fiscal year. Loan funds will be used to retain auditors for the first two
annual  audits  of  the  project  and  corporate  accounts.  Barki  Tajik  will  finance  the  subsequent
annual audits.

 6.

Benefit Monitoring and Evaluation

21

 73.
Barki  Tajik  and  its  environmental  and  social  monitoring  unit  will  carry  out  all  benefit
monitoring and evaluation activities of the Project. These will be undertaken in accordance with
relevant  provisions  of  ADB’s  Benefit Monitoring and Evaluation: A Handbook for Bank Staff,
Staff of Executing Agencies, and Consultants. At the beginning of project implementation, Barki
Tajik  will  submit  to  ADB  a  report  on  the  benchmark  information,  to  be  followed  by  annual
performance  reports  for  at  least  the  first  five  years  of  project  implementation.  Upon  project
completion, a comprehensive report will be submitted. In addition, three years after completion,
Barki Tajik will finance out of its own funds a benefit monitoring and evaluation study to assess
overall benefits of the Project and review the results of the social and environmental monitoring.

74.
Each of the project’s 24,000 beneficiary households in Khatlon Region will be identified
in Barki Tajik’s records to distinguish them from nonproject households. During the benchmark
survey,  annual  reviews,  and  after  completion  of  the  Project,  Barki  Tajik  will  collect  information
on  (i)  cost  of  new  connections  including  metering;  (ii)  increase  in  the  household  electrification
ratio  resulting  from  the  Project;  (iii)  electricity  sales  to  the  newly  connected  households  and
related O&M costs; (iv) new economic activities induced by providing reliable electricity supply;
(v) estimated total value of economic activities induced by rehabilitation of the transmission and
distribution  systems;  (vi)  estimated  average  income  levels;  and  (vii)  perceived  importance  of
various types of noneconomic benefits (disaggregated by gender) created by electricity supply,
such  as  improved  quality  of  life  and  leisure  activities,  better  environment  for  study,  and
improved health standards. Barki Tajik will also concurrently survey average income levels and
other socioeconomic indicators in selected communities where the electricity supply system has
been  and  has  not  been  affected  by  the  Project.  Based  on  this  information,  a  comprehensive
report  on  poverty  reduction  impacts  of  the  Project  will  be  prepared  by  Barki  Tajik  and  be
submitted to ADB within three months after Project completion.

G. 

Executing Agency

1.

Barki Tajik

75.
Barki  Tajik  is  the  state-owned  utility  responsible  for  generation,  transmission,  and
distribution of electricity and heat32 in Tajikistan. Prior to the country’s independence, the entity
was  administratively  part  of  the  FSU's  MOE.  Upon  independence  in  1992,  it  became  a  state
joint stock holding company.33 Although it is fully owned by the Government, Barki Tajik enjoys
autonomous status according to its charter.

 76.
Under  the  present  institutional  arrangement,  Barki  Tajik  consists  of  a  network  of  10
subsidiary power generation companies, 11 subsidiary distribution companies, and 8 supporting
companies  such  as  a  research 
institute  and  construction  companies  (Supplementary
Appendix  G).  The  chairperson  of  Barki  Tajik,  who  has  overall  responsibility  for  operations,
reports directly to the Prime Minister, and is appointed by the Government with no fixed term.
The chairperson is assisted by the first deputy chairperson (chief engineer), who manages Barki
Tajik’s  day-to-day  operations,  and  six  deputy  chairpersons  who  are  in  charge  of  the  technical
departments, supporting services, and subsidiary power generation and distribution companies.
Since 1999, the Government has created business units for some of these subsidiaries,34 with
ownership rights vested directly in the State Property Committee on behalf of the Government
but with business management responsibilities assigned to Barki Tajik.

                  

32 Barki Tajik is responsible for heat supply to Dushanbe and Khujand only.
33 Decree No. 272 of the Cabinet of Ministers of Tajikistan of 24 July 1992.
34 Tursunzade,  Dushanbe  Central,  Khulyab  region,  Khulyab  City,  Ura-Tyube  and  Panjikent  networks;  Baipinskaya

and Pamir hydropower plants; Tajik Energy Construction Enterprise, and Tajikenergo Naladka Installations.

 22

Barki Tajik's organizational structure needs improvement. The roles and responsibilities
77.
between executive and nonexecutive leadership are not clearly defined and there is a relatively
high degree of overlapping of functions and responsibilities between various departments, both
technical  and  commercial.  Therefore,  substantial  changes,  both  organizational  and  regulatory,
are  needed.  In  accordance  with  the  ESAP,  the  corporatization  and  commercialization  of  Barki
Tajik  will  involve  restructuring  along  its  business  unit  lines  for  generation,  transmission,  and
distribution, and a reorganization of its structure.

2. 

Accounting and Financial Management

78.
Barki  Tajik's  accounting  standards  do  not  fully  meet  IAS  requirements.  TA  will  be
provided to Barki Tajik to introduce IAS (para. 96). The accounting and financial management
functions  of  Barki  Tajik’s  subsidiaries  are  managed  by  the  respective  company  accounting
departments. The Central Accounting Department within Barki Tajik’s head office prepares Barki
Tajik’s consolidated financial statements and management reports, and is responsible for cash
flow management. There are 155 accounting staff employed across Barki Tajik, of which 13 are
employed in the head office.

79.
The  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)  regulates  the  accounting  systems  of  state-owned
enterprises. The accounting regulations, while amended in 1997, are not in conformity with IAS.
Barki Tajik submits quarterly and annual financial reports to MOF. MOF, with the assistance of a
tax  committee,  audits  Barki  Tajik's  financial  statements  biennially.  Barki  Tajik's  Planning
Department  is  responsible  for  preparing  the  annual  budget  and  reviewing  it  quarterly.
Computerization of Barki Tajik's accounting procedures in both head office and subsidiaries is
limited.

3.

Past Financial Performance

80.
During  the  FSU  era,  the  power  sector  within  Tajikistan  operated  as  a  part  of  the  MOE
based in Moscow. Tariffs were uniform throughout the FSU, and fuel costs were kept artificially
lower than world prices. Any financial surpluses produced by the power sector were transferred
to  the  state  budget,  which  in  turn  financed  all  Barki  Tajik’s  investment  requirements.  Hence,
there are no long-term borrowings in Barki Tajik’s books.

81.
An  analysis  of  Barki  Tajik’s  past  financial  performance  is  complex  considering  the
noncompliance with IAS, the lack of reliable information, and the high depreciation of the Tajik
ruble.35 Barki Tajik’s financial statements for 1997 to 1999 (Appendix 7), have been restated by
TA consultants (footnote 3) in dollar terms to broadly conform with IAS and are summarized in
Table  6.  Overall,  Barki  Tajik's  past  financial  performance  has  been  weak.  Revenues  have  not
been  sufficient  to  cover  operating  costs  and  returns  on  net  fixed  assets  have  been  negative.
The  collection  efficiency  has  been  low,  resulting  in  high  accounts  receivable.  Furthermore,
human,  managerial,  and  office  resources  have  been  inadequate.  Mainly  because  of  the  Tajik
ruble’s depreciation in 1998, gross revenues, in dollar equivalent, fell from $77.7 million in 1997
to  $44.9  million  in  1998.  Tariff  increases  made  for  residential,  water  supply,  and  public  sector
consumers in 1999 (in dollar terms) resulted in a growth of gross revenues that year. A major
cost item accounting for 37 percent of Barki Tajik's cash operating costs is the import of natural
gas used by the Dushanbe Thermal Power Plant.36 Another major expense (19 percent of the
total)  is  the  purchase  of  electricity,  at  about  $0.05/kWh,  from  Kyrgyz  Republic,  Turkmenistan,

                  

35 From $1=TJR50 in May 1995 to $1=TJR2,000 in August 2000, a depreciation of 97 percent over 64 months.
36 The other thermal power plant, Yavan in the south system, has not operated since 1997.

 23

and Uzbekistan. Under the national accounting system, Barki Tajik had to pay income tax from
1997 to 1999; however, under IAS accounting presentation, Barki Tajik’s operations would have
resulted in net operating losses and not be subject to tax. As of the end of 1999, fixed assets
were grossly undervalued in Barki Tajik’s books, with a total of only $96 million against a gross
replacement  value  estimated  at  about  $3.75  billion.  As  a  result,  tariffs  failed  to  ensure
appropriate capital cost recovery. Barki Tajik’s accounts receivable have been a major problem
with a gross total at the end of 1999 of $67 million, or a net total of $46.8 million after deducting
provision for bad debts; this is the equivalent of 11.4 months of gross billings (paras. 42 to 44).
Retained  earnings  are  minimal  in  Barki  Tajik’s  balance  sheets  as  all  operating  surpluses  are
transferred to the Government.

4.

Financial Projections

A  major  part  of  ADB’s  policy  dialogue  with  the  Government  has  been  devoted  to
82.
improving Barki Tajik’s financial performance. A comprehensive approach has been developed
in the ESAP that involves (i) improving operational efficiency and reducing losses, (ii) improving
the  financial  management  system  and  accounting  standards,  and  (iii)  adjusting  the  level  and
structure of tariffs.

83.
Barki  Tajik’s  financial  projections  are  based  on  agreements  reached  with  the
Government to implement financial reforms that include the following: (i) Barki Tajik will adopt a
debt  service  covenant  of  at  least  1.3  times;  (ii)  the  Government  will  undertake  all  necessary
actions, including base tariff increases and implementation of tariff adjustments arising from the
quarterly automatic tariff adjustment mechanism, to ensure that Barki Tajik's operating ratio will
be below 90 percent from 2002 on, and Barki Tajik will generate a rate of return of 6 percent on
net fixed assets from the end of 2005 on; and (iii) Barki Tajik will reduce accounts receivable to
the  equivalent  of  six  months  of  billings  by  December  2001  and  three  months  of  billings  by
December 2002.

84. With  the  implementation  of  these  measures,  Barki  Tajik’s  financial  performance  is
expected  to  gradually  improve  (Appendix  7  and  Table  6).  The  financial  projections  assume
annual  tariff  increases  in  dollar  terms  of  22  percent  in  2000,  25  percent  between  2001  and
2005, and 10 percent thereafter. Such increases are realistic given the low tariff level and the
application of the lifeline tariff which benefits mostly the poor. Electricity sales are conservatively
estimated to grow at 2.0 percent per year between 2000 and 2002, at an average of 3.2 percent
per  year  between  2003  and  2004,  and  at  an  average  of  5.3  percent  per  year  from  2005  to
2015.37 The operating ratio is expected to deteriorate in 2000, mainly due to the revaluation of
Barki Tajik’s fixed assets and resulting depreciation expenses, but will gradually improve to 77
percent  by  2003.  After  generating  a  negative  return  on  net  fixed  assets  during  2000  and
breaking even in 2001, Barki Tajik is expected to yield a rate of return of 6.7 percent by 2005.

37 In 1998 and 1999, the sales growth was 24 percent and 7 percent respectively.

H. 

Environmental and Social Measures

1.

Environmental Impacts

85.
The  Project  is  not  expected  to  have  any  major  adverse  impact  on  the  environment.  It
consists entirely of rehabilitation of existing structures and facilities. The rehabilitation includes
replacing switchgear and transformers at existing substations, rehabilitating existing hydropower
plant components, and retrofitting new components to existing equipment. The Project has been
classified as Category B in ADB’s environmental classification system. An initial environmental
examination  was  undertaken  according  to  ADB’s  guidelines  at  the  feasibility  study  stage
(Appendix 8).

86.
During  construction,  there  could  be  air  pollution  and  noise  caused  by  trucks  and  other
vehicles for transport of materials and use of machines at sites. However, due to (i) the limited
scope and duration of construction, (ii) the type of materials to be transported, and (iii) the fact
that  measures  in  NHPP  take  place  outside  inhabited  areas,  no  negative  impact  requiring
specific mitigation measures will occur. An estimated 0.5-1.0 million cubic meters of material will
have  to  be  excavated  from  the  NHPP  dam  tailrace.  An  uninhabited  unlevel  area  of  about
7  hectares  has  been  identified  near  the  construction  site  as  appropriate  for  depositing  the
excavated  material.  The  land  belongs  to  the  local  government  and  Barki  Tajik  has  obtained
authorization  to  use  the  excavated  material  to  fill  the  uneven  pockets.  The  material  to  be
excavated will not present any environmental risk and consists of rocks and sediments. Positive
environmental  impacts  from  this  are  expected  since  tree  cover  can  be  established  once  the
filled area is leveled. The Project requires replacement of about 500 tons of transformer oil that
does  not  contain  any  poly-chlorine-biphenyl,  which  would  be  hazardous  to  health  and  the
environment. During replacement of transformers, this oil will be filtered and recycled for use as
fuel by Barki Tajik. The Government and Barki Tajik have agreed to remove and dispose of all
hazardous  waste  materials  associated  with  the  Project,  in  a  safe  and  environmentally
responsible manner.

 2.

Social Aspects

25

87.
Under the project preparatory TA (footnote 4), an initial social assessment was carried
out  and  a  summary  of  the  assessment  was  prepared  according  to  the  ADB  guidelines
(Appendix  9).  This  assessment  has  shown  that  the  risk  of  negative  socioeconomic  impacts  is
small  or  nonexistent.  None  of  the  components  identified  will  require  any  resettlement,  and  no
additional  land  is  required  except  for  the  7  hectares  near  NHPP.  The  improvement  of  energy
supply in the project areas will substantially improve the well-being of the people.

Electricity supply is a prerequisite for improving the economic situation and quality of life
88.
in  the  project  areas,  as  it  is  required  for  agriculture  (irrigation  and  drainage),  drinking  water
supply,  health,  education,  industry,  and  small-scale  enterprises.  Adequate  energy  supply  will
remove  an  important  obstacle  to  investments,  and  facilitate  operation  of  private  enterprises.
Agriculture  will  benefit  due  to  improved  irrigation  and  drainage.  Direct  and  indirect  health
benefits include (i) improved drainage that will reduce the risks from malaria, and saline water in
farmland  and  water  table,  (ii)  improved  water  supply  through  use  of  electric  pumps,  and  (iii)
ability  to  boil  water  efficiently  thus  reducing  risks  from  unsafe  water.  Provision  of  lighting  and
heating in schools will improve the education facilities and increase school enrolment.

3. 

Gender and Development

89.
Based  on  UNDP's  gender-related  development  index,  which  fell  from  0.57  in  1995  to
0.53  in  1998,  the  relative  position  of  women  has  deteriorated.  Women  are  more  likely  to  be
unemployed than men: the unemployment rates are 28.8 percent for women and 25.3 percent
for  men.38  Women’s  wages  average  only  $2  per  month  as  compared  with  men’s  wages
averaging  $6  per  month.  Women  spend  an  average  of  6.3  hours  per  day  of  unpaid  work
(cooking, working on private plots, cleaning, laundry, etc.) compared to 3.3 hours by men. The
war  has  left  an  estimated  26,000  widows  and  55,000  orphans  who  are  even  more  severely
affected.

90. Women  and  children  disproportionately  bear  the  burden  of  using  alternative  fuels  to
augment the lack of reliable electricity supply. Such use has economic, time, labor, health, and
social  impacts.  A  one-month  supply  of  fuelwood  takes  up  to  15  days  to  gather.  Work  on  cow
dung  briquettes  takes  at  least  one  hour  per  day  per  household  during  the  summer  to  prepare
the  required  supply  for  winter.  The  use  of  these  energy  sources,  typically  for  cooking  in
unventilated  rooms,  constitutes  health  hazards 
for  women  and  children,  who  spend
approximately five hours per day in such rooms. Prior to independence, piped water had been
provided to households. However, pumping from reservoirs and deep-wells has been restricted
because  of  the  current  irregular  electricity  supply.  Women  and  children  in  particular  fetch
drinking  water  which  takes  substantial  amount  of  time,  as  they  need  to  walk  up  to  15  km  to
water sources. Due to transportation and storage, water obtained is often contaminated, and is
frequently not boiled due to scarcity of electricity. Consequently, the Project will have significant
positive impacts on poor women and children, particularly in Khatlon Region, in better health, a
reduced burden of household chores, and increased time for economic activities.

4.

Poverty Reduction and Improving the Quality of Life of the Poor

91.
The  serious  energy  shortage,  particularly  in  rural  areas  and  mainly  during  winter,  has
been  identified  by  the  Government,  households,  community  development  organizations,
nongovernment  organizations,  and  international  aid  agencies  as  one  of  the  most  important

38 Falkingham, J. 1999. Women and Gender Relations in Tajikistan. London School of Economics, London.

                  

 26

challenges to reducing poverty and improving the quality of life of the poor. Unless addressed,
Tajikistan  will  have  difficulty  resuming  economic  growth;  increasing  agricultural  and  industrial
productivity;  generating  employment;  increasing  incomes;  and  meeting  basic  needs  such  as
heating, safe water, and social services. Restoration and improvement of electricity supply is a
prerequisite for reducing poverty, improving quality of life, and sustaining economic growth.

Participatory  rural  assessments  conducted  during  project  preparation39  confirmed  high
92.
levels  of  poverty,  particularly  in  rural  areas.  Formal  employment  is  low,  and,  where  available,
consists  mostly  of  civil  service  employment  where  salaries  are  often  several  months  late;  or
seasonal  employment  in  collective  farms  paying  TJR2,000  ($1)  per  month  during  spring  and
TJR10,000  ($5)  per  month  during  summer.  Formal  employment  for  women  is  even  less
available.  Women  spend  more  time  than  men  at  home  doing  unpaid  work.  Households
supplement their incomes through home plots, milk production, livestock, and small-scale retail
activities.  In  most  households  visited,  these  activities  constituted  the  main  source  of  income.
Most  income  is  received  during  summer  and  fall  harvest  season,  but  most  expenses  are
incurred  during  winter  and  spring,  mainly  for  heating  and  clothing.  Poor  households  receive
humanitarian  aid  from  donor  agencies  through  the  local  government,  consisting  of  5  liters  of
cooking oil and/or 10 kilos of flour supplied every 3-6 months.

93.
In the project areas, households report that electricity is available intermittently for most
of the year except during the winter (December to March), when electricity is available only for
2-4 hours a day. Because of lack of electricity, people have shifted to alternative sources of fuel.
Households spend as much as TJR25,000 (including time and cost) for fuelwood during winter
months,  and  where  fuelwood  is  scarce,  animal  dung  is  used  exclusively,  averaging  1,500
briquettes  during  the  winter  and  300  briquettes  during  the  rest  of  the  year,  which  is  valued  at
TJR15,000  mainly  for  labor  cost.  Diesel  is  primarily  used  for  lighting  and  igniting  fuelwood  or
animal dung, and its cost can reach TJR18,000 during winter months. Field visits confirmed that
the Project would have substantial impacts on reduction of poverty and improving the quality of
life  of  the  poor  through  provision  of  cheaper  and  reliable  electricity  supply  (valued  at  a  lifeline
tariff  of  $0.003/kWh  against  alternative  fuel  costs  of  about  $0.032/kWh)  and  freeing  up  time
used for gathering and using alternative fuels for generating additional income (e.g., working on
home plots, bread making, and sewing). In addition, the scarcity of electricity has health, social
and gender impacts (para. 90).

94.
The large  agricultural base,  which is dependent on irrigation, has suffered from lack of
pumping facilities. As a result, farm yield has dropped to 20-25 percent of levels when Tajikistan
was part of the FSU. The provision of reliable electricity supply through the Project will reduce
poverty  by  increasing  farming  activity  and  providing  employment  opportunities  to  the  poor  in
particular.  The  provision  of  education  and  health  services  to  the  population  is  similarly
hampered by lack of electricity, thus reducing the quality of life of the poor in particular. Schools
are  closed  for  two  months  during  winter  due  to  inadequate  electricity  for  heating.  This  forces
schools to operate for extended hours during summer. School enrolment has dropped because
poor children, lacking warm clothes and shoes, do not attend school during the rest of winter.
Hospitals  also  lack  heating,  and  delivery  of  services  is  greatly  hampered  by  lack  of  electricity
supply.  In  particular,  crucial  medicines  and  vaccines  cannot  be  properly  stored  at  controlled
conditions.  Hospitals  that  remain  operational  are  in  urban  administrative  centers,  resulting  in
high transportation costs and long travel time leading to even higher expenses for the poor who
live far from the centers. The Project will improve people's quality of life (especially for the poor)
by providing reliable and adequate electricity supply to schools and hospitals.

I.

Technical Assistance

95.
To  help  Barki  Tajik  meet  targets  set  under  the  ESAP,  the  Government  requested  two
TAs40  to  be  provided  under  the  Project.  The  first  TA,  Improving  Barki  Tajik's  Billing  and
Collection System, will help Barki Tajik design and implement a billing and collection system to
reduce  its  accounts  receivable.  The  TA  will  (i)  cover  implementation  of  a  pilot  computerized
system  to  support  the  billing  and  collection  system  at  a  large  distribution  subsidiary,  (ii)
formulate  recommendations  for  improvement  of  the  consumer  management  process  covering
billing and collection for electricity customers, and (iii) provide training for Barki Tajik staff in the
use  of  the  system.  About  12  person-months  of  international  and  about  10  person-months  of
domestic consulting services will be required. The study will be carried out by an international
accounting firm with expertise in consumer accounting, financial management, and information
systems. The terms of reference are given in Supplementary Appendix H. The total cost of the
TA is estimated at $586,000 equivalent, with a foreign exchange cost of $492,000 and a local
currency  cost  of  $94,000  equivalent.  $500,000  equivalent  will  be  financed  by  ADB  on  a  grant
basis  from  the  Japan  Special  Fund  funded  by  the  Government  of  Japan,  to  cover  the  entire
foreign  exchange  costs  and  part  of  the  local  currency  costs  amounting  to  $8,000  equivalent.
The  remaining  local  currency  cost  of  $86,000  equivalent,  representing  15  percent  of  the  total
cost of the TA, will be financed by Barki Tajik to cover (i) counterpart staff, (ii) local transport for
consultants  and  counterpart  staff,  (iii)  secretarial  support  and  office  supplies,  and  (iv)  office
accommodation. The TA is expected to commence in May 2001 and will require about 8 months
to be completed.

The  second  TA,  Introducing  IAS  at  Barki  Tajik,  will  help  Barki  Tajik  introduce  IAS  and
96.
prepare its corporate accounts for the year 2001 in line with both national regulations and IAS.
Barki  Tajik’s  accounting  practices  are  rudimentary  and  need  to  be  improved  to  reflect  its
financial situation correctly. Enhanced accounting practices will also support systems to improve
cost  recovery  and  reduce  accounts  receivable.  Approximately  11.5  person-months  of
international and 10-person months of domestic consulting services are required. The study will
be  carried  out  by  an  international  accounting  firm  with  expertise  in  accounting,  financial
management,  and  information  systems.  The  terms  of  reference  are  given  in  Supplementary
Appendix  I.  The  total  cost  of  the  TA  is  estimated  at  $586,000  equivalent,  with  a  foreign
exchange  cost  of  $490,000  and  a  local  currency  cost  of  $96,000  equivalent.  $500,000
equivalent will be financed by ADB on a grant basis from the Japan Special Fund funded by the
Government of Japan, to cover the entire foreign exchange costs and part of the local currency
costs amounting to $10,000 equivalent. The remaining local currency cost of $86,000 equivalent
(representing  15  percent  of  the  total  cost  of  the  TA)  will  be  financed  by  Barki  Tajik  to  cover
(i)  counterpart  staff,  (ii)  local  transport  for  consultants  and  counterpart  staff,  (iii)  secretarial
support and office supplies, and (iv) office accommodation. The TA is expected to commence in
July 2001 and will require about 10 months to be completed.

97.
Both  TAs  are  essential  for  the  commercialization  of  Barki  Tajik  and  will  facilitate  the
creation  of  an  appropriate  new  organizational  structure.  For  both  TAs,  full  technical  proposals
will  be  requested  from  shortlisted  firms,  and  consultants  will  be  engaged  in  accordance  with
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements acceptable to ADB on the
engagement of domestic consultants.

V.

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

A. 

Financial and Economic Analyses

1. 

Least Cost Analysis

98.
During  the  feasibility  study  (footnote  4),  a  large  number  of  potential  alternatives,
including a do-nothing option, and their costs have been analyzed. For example, dredging of the
NHPP tailrace was compared with four options: (i) import of an additional 320 GWh of energy,
(ii) build a new hydro or diesel power plant providing 320 GWh, (iii) increase turbine efficiency
with new runners, and (iv) do nothing. In a similar manner, least cost options were examined for
other project-components, with more than 25 options considered in all. This analysis confirmed
that all project components are part of the least cost plan for power development in Tajikistan.

2. 

Financial Analysis

Financial analysis for the Project from the perspective of Barki Tajik is based on capital
99.
costs of $52.9 million—base costs plus physical contingencies, assuming an economic life of 15
years—5  years  for  construction  and  10  years  for  operation41  (Appendix  10).  Incremental
benefits  of  the  Project  are  based  on  a  "with  project"  and  "without  project"  comparison  and
include  the  incremental  energy  generated,  improved  reliability  of  power  supply,  and  avoided
electricity  losses.42  In  particular,  such  incremental  benefits  are  expected  to  be  gained  from  (i)
increased  power  generation  and  supply  reliability  in  Khatlon  Region  due  to  improved  voltage
and  uninterrupted  electricity  supply,  avoided  technical  losses,  and  reduction  of  substandard
inefficient  connections;  (ii)  increased  power  generation  and  supply  reliability  through  the
rehabilitation  of  NHPP;  and  (iii)  increased  power  supply  reliability  and  transmission  efficiency
through  the  rehabilitation  of  the  Novaya  and  Djangal  substations.  These  incremental  benefits
are measured in billed electricity sales estimated at about 7.6 TWh during the period of analysis,
and valued at average revenue as per financial projections for Barki Tajik (but at constant year
2000 prices). On this basis, and after allowance for adequate O&M costs and income tax, the
financial internal rate of return (FIRR) for the Project is 7.7 percent. The weighted average cost
of  project  capital  has  not  been  determined,  because  the  uncertain  economic  conditions
prevailing in Tajikistan do not allow determination of an indicative set of interest rates and rates
of return. However, the FIRR level indicates that the Project is financially viable in comparison
with the onlending rate to Barki Tajik. The results of sensitivity analysis, which are summarized
in Table 7, show that the Project remains financially viable with changes in key assumptions.

 3.

Economic Analysis

29

100.
The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  has  also  been  estimated  comparing  the
"with project" and "without project" scenarios following ADB’s Guidelines for Economic Analysis
of Projects (Appendix 11). All applicable assumptions used for the financial analysis have been
maintained  for  the  economic  analysis.  In  addition,  for  the  economic  analysis,  (i)  capital  and
operating  cost  data  taken  from  the  financial  analysis  have  been  adjusted  to  reflect  economic
values; and  (ii) in  calculating the  economic capital costs, all duties, taxes, and subsidies have
been excluded. Total electricity demand has been divided into incremental and nonincremental
components. The nonincremental part of energy demand is assumed to be about two-thirds of
total demand and is valued at resource cost savings. The incremental part is valued in terms of
users’ willingness to pay. All tradable commodities are valued at border price at the prevailing
exchange rate (TJR2,000 = $1). Nontradable commodities are valued at shadow price using a
standard conversion factor of 0.9.

101. On  this  basis,  the  EIRR  for  the  Project  is  28.0  percent,  which  is  well  above  ADB’s
threshold for economic viability of 12 percent. The net present value of the Project is estimated
at  TJR84.6  billion  at  12  percent  discount  rate.  Sensitivity  analysis  has  been  carried  out  for
increased  capital  cost,  reduced  benefits,  implementation  delay,  change  in  willingness  to  pay,
and a combination of cases (Table 8). The assumptions made are conservative, the estimated
economic  indicators  robust,  the  poverty  reduction  impacts  substantial,  and  the  project
components  part  of  the  least  cost  plan  for  power  development.  Consequently,  the  proposed
Project is considered economically justified.

102.
The rehabilitation of NHPP, CHPP, and transmission and distribution systems will benefit
the people in Tajikistan directly (about 1 million people or 172,000 households) and indirectly.
The reduced electricity losses and inefficiencies in direct utilization for household activities will
make  more  electricity  available  and  improve  the  well-being  of  the  population  in  the  project
areas,  in  particular  during  winter.  The  difference  between  the  financial  and  economic  net
present  values,  and  consequent  gains  and  losses  for  different  stakeholders,  provide  the  basis
for  considering the  impact  of the Project on the poor. For the poverty impact assessment, the
project  beneficiaries  are  divided  into  three  groups:  consumers,  Government  economy,  and
labor.  The  net  economic  benefits  by  group  are  distributed  between  poor  and  nonpoor.  The
increased, more efficient, and reliable electricity supply resulting from the Project will benefit the
poor directly and indirectly. Net economic benefits accruing to the poor are estimated at about
$27  million  (Appendix  12).    The  poverty  impact  ratio,  which  expresses  the  proportion  of  net
economic  benefits  of  the  Project  accruing  to  the  poor,  is  estimated  at  57  percent.  This  is

 30

conservative  as  some  indirect  economic  and  social  benefits  are  not  considered.  Hence,  a
substantial  portion  of  the  project  benefits  will  go  to  the  poor  and  the  Project  can  achieve  its
primary objective of poverty reduction.

103.
The  participatory  rural  assessments  (footnote  39)  confirmed  that  the  Project  would
reduce  poverty.  The  project  areas  are  characterized  by  high  levels  of  poverty  and  are  largely
rural. Due to climatic conditions, electricity is a basic need for heat, cooking, and irrigation water
in the project areas. The Project will also support improvement of other essential services such
as  drinking  water,  education,  and  health.  Adequate  and  reliable  electricity  will  help  generate
jobs  through  (i)  economic  development,  and  (ii)  reduction  of  time  spent  obtaining  and  using
energy  alternatives  for  productive  activities.  This  will  have  significant  impact  on  vulnerable
groups, particularly women and children.

104. Part  A  of  the  Project  will  have  the  greatest  impact  on  the  poor  because  it  will  improve
power  supply  for  approximately  24,000  households  comprised  mostly  of  civil  war  returnees  in
Khatlon Region. Field visits confirmed that returnees are among the poorest segment of society.
The collective farm Sovhoz 2 in the war-affected Bishkent District is of particular importance for
agricultural  production  (para.  54).  The  substation  rehabilitation  will  provide  power  to  the
pumping  station,  which  will  considerably  improve  conditions  for  agricultural  production  in  the
district and reduce constraints on the development of small industries.

105. Electricity is required for economic growth and higher incomes, but it cannot be supplied
at the current low prices on a sustainable basis. The prevalent extreme levels of poverty affect
the ability of a significant portion of the population to pay higher electricity prices. If Barki Tajik is
unable  to  collect  its  bills,  the  power  system  will  eventually  collapse,  making  the  poor  even
worse-off.  The  Government  has  studied  several  possibilities  of  introducing  social  safety
measures  to  subsidize  electricity  for  the  poorest  segment  of  the  population  (Appendix  13).
During the policy dialogue, the Government has agreed that in the medium term, there will be
no  real  increases  in  the  tariff  for  an  initial  household  consumption  of  150  kWh  per  month.
A  study  of  alternative  fuel  costs  paid  by  poor  households  shows  that  the  current  tariff  of
TJR5/kWh  to  be  applied  to  this  lifeline  consumption  is  affordable.  As  83  percent  of  the
population  live  below  the  poverty  line,  such  an  arrangement  is  considered  justified.  The
Government also proposes to use the interest margin arising from relending the loan from ADB
and  cofinancing  from  the  Swiss  Government  to  Barki  Tajik  to  fund  the  subsidy  for  the  lifeline
tariff.  If  required,  the  Government  will  make  up  for  any  shortfall  in  the  subsidy  to  Barki  Tajik.
Under the ESAP, by January 2002, the Government is to provide proposals, acceptable to ADB,
for a safety net to protect the poor and vulnerable groups adequately with regard to impact of
tariff  increases  in  the  long  term.  Measures  to  be  considered  include  changes  to  the  tariff
structure for residential consumers, and the provision of a well targeted cash subsidy scheme to
the poor and vulnerable groups.

B. 

Environment

106.
The  Project  will  have  considerable  environmental  benefits,  mainly  through  reducing
losses  in  energy  production  at  NHPP;  eliminating  the  risk  of  NHPP's  switchyard  collapsing
which  could  lead  to  oil  from  the  transformers  contaminating  the  Vaksh  River;  improving  dam
safety  at  NHPP;  reducing  electricity  losses  in  the  distribution  system  in  Khatlon  Region;  and
reducing  pressure  on  alternative  sources  of  energy,  mainly  fuelwood43  and  other  biomass
resources.

43 The forest cover in Tajikistan is only 2.3 percent.

                  

 C.

Social Dimensions

31

107.
The  risk  of  negative  socioeconomic  impacts  from  the  Project  is  small  or  nonexistent.
Since the Project focuses only on rehabilitation of existing facilities, none of the components will
require any resettlement. About 7 hectares of uninhabited land is required as a dumping ground
for rocks and sediments from the dredging of Vaksh River and Barki Tajik has already received
the  local  government's  approval  to  use  this  land  at  no  cost  (para.  86).  The  Project  will
substantially  improve  the  social  well-being  of  about  172,000  households,  most  of  which  are
poor.  Given  the  climate  in  the  project  areas,  electricity  is  a  basic  need  for  heat,  cooking,  and
pumping  of  safe  drinking  water.  The  Project  will  also  support  the  improvement  of  essential
services  such  as  irrigation  and  drainage,  education,  and  health;  facilitate  direct  employment;
and  help  generate  jobs  through  induced  economic  development  and  by  releasing  time  spent
searching  for  and  using  energy  alternatives  for  more  productive  activities.  This  will  have
significant impacts on vulnerable groups, particularly women and children.

D.

Risks

108. Risks affecting the Project may be divided into two broad categories. Short- to medium-
term  risks  are  associated  with  implementation  and  the  achievement  of  immediate  output.  The
long-term strategic risks relate to the overall impact and sustainability of improvements brought
about  by  the  Project.  The  former  risks  are  related  to  availability  of  local  funds,  timeliness  in
project implementation, and adequate project management. The Government has assured ADB
that the Project is given top priority for the economic development of Tajikistan, the necessary
funds  will  be  made  available  in  a  timely  manner,  and  adequate  measures  will  be  taken  to
improve Barki Tajik’s financial situation. Given that this is ADB’s first power project in Tajikistan,
problems could be encountered in its implementation because of Barki Tajik's unfamiliarity  with
policies and practices of multilateral financing institutions. This risk will be mitigated through the
provision  of  (i)  adequate  and  continued  implementation  consulting  services;  (ii)  an  adequate
time  period  to  complete  the  Project,  taking  into  account  ADB's  experience  in  other  transition
economies; and (iii) regular training by ADB and the project implementation consultants for PIU
and  Barki  Tajik  staff  in  matters  related  to  procurement,  project  management,  social  and
environmental 
loan  disbursement.  Adequate  project
management will also be ensured through ADB approval for key positions in the PIU.

issues,  benefit  monitoring,  and 

109.
In the long term, the risks associated with the sustainability of project benefits are related
to  (i)  the  political  stability  in  Tajikistan,  (ii)  the  Government's  commitment  to  energy  sector
reform and periodic electricity tariff increases, (iii) Barki Tajik's financial position, (iv) adequate
maintenance  of  project  facilities,  and  (v)  the  provision  of  an  adequate  safety  net  for  poor  and
vulnerable  groups  against  tariff  increases.  The  political  situation  in  Tajikistan  is  improving  as
evidenced by the reduced need for UN peace-keeping efforts in future.44 Under the PCIPL, the
Government is committed to reform the energy sector by (i) developing a legal and regulatory
framework  for  efficient  energy  sector  operations,  (ii)  increasing  the  level  of  electricity  tariffs
toward  full  cost  recovery,  (iii)  encouraging  private  sector  participation  in  the  generation  and
distribution  of  power,  and  (iv)  promoting  energy  conservation.  While  progress  in  these  areas
slowed  recently  partly  due  to  the  poor  economic  situation  in  the  country  and  the  general
elections,  the  Government  nevertheless  remains  committed  to  the  reform  program  and  has

                  

44 After independence in 1991, Tajikistan suffered a five-year civil war. A peace agreement, signed in 1997, provided
the  basis  for  national  reconciliation  and  established  a  framework  for  holding  parliamentary  elections.  Despite
occasional disruptions, the peace process made significant progress in 1998 and 1999. Tajikistan’s President was
re-elected in November 1999. Holding parliamentary elections, which were completed in March 2000 as scheduled,
concluded  the  peace  process.  The  UN  Security  Council  withdrew  its  observers  from  Tajikistan  in  May  2000  and
opened a small office in Dushanbe to support the country’s stability.

 32

agreed to continue the reform agenda through adoption of the ESAP, with emphasis on full cost
recovery for electricity supply  and  restructuring of Barki Tajik to improve its accountability and
financial  viability.  To  verify  Barki  Tajik’s  performance  in  meeting  financial  covenants  set  under
the  Project,  consulting  services  will  be  provided  to  audit  Barki  Tajik’s  corporate  and  project
accounts  for  2000  and  2001  in  accordance  with  IAS.  In  conjunction  with  the  Project,  two  TAs
(paras.  95-97)  will  help  Barki  Tajik  improve  its  billing  and  collection  system  to  reduce  its
accounts  receivable,  and  to  introduce  IAS  at  Barki  Tajik  to  make  its  corporate  accounts
compatible with international practices. With regard to maintenance, the proper maintenance of
project facilities is essential for the sustainability of project benefits. The Government and Barki
Tajik have agreed to implement recommendations of implementation consultants and to provide
for  adequate  funds  annually  for  O&M.  The  Government  also  places  priority  on  protecting  the
poor  and  vulnerable  groups  from  the  impact  of  tariff  increases,  and  in  that  regard  the
Government  agreed  to  maintain  the  lifeline  tariff  structure  in  the  medium  term  and  to  use  the
interest margin arising from onlent funds to Barki Tajik to fund the subsidy for the lifeline tariff.

Appendix 7, page 1

FINANCIAL PERFORMANCE AND PROJECTIONS OF BARKI TAJIK

1.    
The financial statements of Barki Tajik are presented in Tables A7.1 to A7.3. Figures for
1997-1999 are based on actual operations while those for 2000-2010 are projections based on
notes and assumptions described below.

A. 

Prices, Inflation, and Exchange Rate

2.     Since the country’s independence, the Tajik ruble has continually devalued against the
US  dollar.  The  exchange  rate  per  US  dollar  decreased  from  TJR50  in  1995  to  TJR2,000  in
2000,  a  depreciation  of  97  percent  in  five  years.  Year-to-year  inflation  was  170  percent  in
September 1997; this fell to 2.7 percent by December 1998, but rose to 64 percent by August
1999.  The  medium-term  and  long-term  stability  of  both  local  inflation  and  the  Tajik  ruble
exchange rate has not yet been established. The financial projections have been carried out in
current  dollar  equivalents  considering  the  difficulty  projecting  prices  of  goods  and  services  in
Tajik ruble. Prices in dollar terms are assumed to increase in accordance with the international
inflation rate, estimated at 2.4 percent per year throughout the projection period.

B. 

Income Statement

3.     Revenues.  Electricity  sales  are  estimated  to  grow  at  2  percent  per  year  during  2000-
2002 and at an average of 3.2 percent during 2003-2004. With full realization of the benefits of
the  Project,  sales  are  expected  to  grow  by  an  average  of  5.3  percent  annually  during  2005-
2015.  The  forecast  increase  in  sales  growth  is  lower  than  the  actual  growth  in  1997-1999
considering  that  Barki  Tajik's  generation  capacity  is  limited  by  the  poor  operating  condition  of
the power plants. The average tariff as of August 2000 amounts to $0.0045/kilowatt-hour (kWh).
To achieve financial cost recovery and a return of 6 percent on net fixed assets by 2005, it is
assumed that the average revenue will be increased by 25 percent annually during 2001-2005.

4.     Operating Expenses. Fuel consumption is based on the requirements of the generating
units.  Fuel  used  in  the  Dushanbe  Thermal  Power  Plant  is  imported  from  Uzbekistan  at  about
$50-55 per thousand cubic meters. Annual operating and maintenance expenses are estimated
at 1.0 percent of gross fixed assets. Annual depreciation is calculated on a straight-line basis at
2.5 percent of revalued gross fixed assets.

Interest and Taxes. Interest expenses on long-term debt are calculated on the indicated

5.    
terms and conditions on committed loans. Taxable income is subject to 30 percent income tax.

C. 

Balance Sheet

6.    
Fixed Assets. The fixed assets have been significantly undervalued in previous years. It
is assumed that the assets will be revalued in 2000 with an estimated gross replacement value
of $3.75 billion and an accumulated depreciation of $2.5 billion.

 47

Appendix 7, page 2

7.     Accounts Receivable. It is expected that accounts receivable will amount to six months
gross sales by 2001 and further improve to three months gross sales by 2002. Provision for bad
debts is made annually for 10 percent of the previous year’s outstanding accounts receivable.

Long-Term  Debt.  Long-term  debts  take  into  account  the  financing  required  for  the
8.    
Project and the capital investment program of Barki Tajik. Financial conditions for the additional
loans are assumed to be similar to those for project loans.

D. 

Cash Flow Statement

9.     Capital  Investment  Program.  The  medium-term  capital  investment  plan  is  based  on
Barki Tajik’s indicated rehabilitation projects planned for the period 2001-2005.

10.     Dividends.  It  is  assumed  that  dividends  will  be  declared  whenever  the  year-end  cash
balance exceeds minimum cash balance operating requirements.

SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION

A. 

Introduction

1.
The  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  study  was  undertaken  by  consultants  as  a
part  of  the  technical  assistance  (TA)1  financed  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB).  The
summary IEE report covers the environmental aspects of the proposed Project. The Project has
five parts and it covers mainly central and southern regions including Dushanbe, the capital of
the country. ADB fact-finding and appraisal missions visited the sites and held discussions with
government  agencies,  local  government  representatives,  district  officers,  Barki  Tajik  (the  state
power company) representatives, and local residents during 10 to 25 April and 14 to 29 August
2000.  ADB  classified  the  Project  as  environmental  category  B.  Barki  Tajik,  the  Executing
Agency,  prepared  the  summary  IEE  for  the  Project  with  the  inputs  from  IEE,  TA  consultants,
and ADB Missions.

B.

Description of the Project

2.
The  aim  of  the  Project  is  to  improve  power  supply  to  end  users  in  Tajikistan.  As  a
consequence of the break-up of the Soviet Union and the civil war from 1992 to 1996, much of
the  electricity  installations  were  destroyed  or  damaged  in  the  country.  The  heavily  degraded
electricity  transmission  and  distribution  systems  are  not  capable  of  providing  adequate
electricity supply to the end users, particularly poor and rural households.

3.
The  Project  comprises  five  parts.  Part  A  consists  of  improving  the  power  supply  in
Khatlon  Region,  the  region  south  of  the  country.  In  addition  to  the  general  degradation  of  the
transmission,  distribution,  and  supply  network  due  to  minimal  maintenance  over  the  last  10
years,  the  electricity  supply  network  in  this  region  has  suffered  considerably  from  the
consequences  of  the  civil  war.  This  component  of  the  Project  will  improve  power  supply  to  a
large number of households, mainly civil war returnee villages. One specific component consists
of rehabilitating the Sovhoz 2 substation, in the Bishkent District. The rehabilitation will provide
electricity to a drainage pumping station that in the past provided drainage for 2,500 hectares of
land, giving employment to 10,000 people. Because of the lack of reliable electricity supply, the
land is heavily waterlogged and certain areas are flooded and cannot be cultivated. Well water
has become saline, requiring villagers to collect drinking water from the river. Part B comprises
rehabilitation measures at Nurek Hydropower Plant (NHPP), the most important power plant in
Tajikistan.  Part  B  consists  of    (i)  improvement  measures  at  the  220  kilovolt  (kV)  switchyard;
(ii)  improvement  of  the  NHPP  tailrace;  (iii)  NHPP  dam  monitoring;  and  (iv)  improvement  of
Regar  500  kV  and  220  kV  substations,  through  which  a  significant  portion  of  the  electricity
supplied  in  Dushanbe  region  is  delivered,  together  with  the  main  export-import  to  Uzbekistan
and  the  Central  Asia  grid.  Part  C  comprises  rehabilitation  of  two  220/110  kV  substations  at
Novaya  and  Djangal,  by  repairing  and  partially  replacing  electromechanical  equipment.  These
two substations are main supply points for Dushanbe region, with about 1 million people. Part D
will provide funds for about 500 high voltage electronic meters to be installed at power stations
and high voltage substations to measure exported and imported energy, generated and sent-out
energy,  and  the  energy  exchanged  between  each  of  Barki  Tajik’s  regional  distribution
organizations. Project implementation consulting services are provided under Part E.

C.

Description of the Environment

1.

Physical Resources

Tajikistan  is  characterized  by  a  strongly  continental  climate  with  hot,  dry  summers  and
4.
cold  winters,  especially  in  mountainous  areas.  Daily  temperature  fluctuations  are  usually  quite
large.  The  cold  winters  make  heating  a  necessity  for  winter  months  in  the  whole  country.
Approximately 97 percent of the country is mountainous, and almost half of it is at altitudes of
more than 3,000 meters above sea level. The few flat areas available are intensively used for
agriculture, which is done almost exclusively under irrigation. For this reason, the considerable
water resources of the country, stemming from the high mountain areas, are important for power
generation as well as for irrigation. A large proportion of the irrigated areas lies in Khatlon, the
region where power supply will be improved by the Project.

2.

Biological Resources

The project area consists mainly of two parts: (i) the immediate surroundings of NHPP,
5.
and  (ii)  the  inhabited  areas  of  the  whole  of  Khatlon  Region.  Both  these  areas  are  intensively
used  and  occupied  by  human  activities.  These  areas  have  no  rare  or  endangered  species  of
wildlife or plants, and the Project will not have any negative effects on biological resources.

6.
The construction of the NHPP dam undoubtedly affected its environment, especially the
river  ecosystem.  However,  the  present  Project  will  not  influence  or  change  the  impacts  of  the
existing dam. Information about the situation before the dam was built in 1962 is not available.
Forests are a very rare resource in Tajikistan; only about 2.3 percent of the country is currently
covered  with  forests.  The  reduction  of  fuel  imports,  particularly  gas  from  Uzbekistan  and  coal
from Russia, has led to an increase in pressure on forests.

3.

Human and Economic Development

7.
Studies,  including  surveys  made  by  the  TA  consultants,  uniformly  show  a  population
which  that  is  largely  (83  percent)  below  the  poverty  line.  In  some  of  the  districts  that  will  be
served by the Project, more than half of the population left their homes during the civil war for
other countries. Most have returned, but face a difficult situation, because many of their houses
have been destroyed. Electricity supply is unreliable due to damaged and deficient installations,
and  often  dangerous  because  of  makeshift  electricity  connections.  The  Project  (Part  A)  will
improve this situation.

8.
Agriculture, mainly under irrigation, is the most important economic activity, and cotton is
the  most  important  product.  Since  much  of  the  irrigation  requires  electric  pumps,  the
improvement  of  electricity  supply  will  contribute  to  an  improvement  in  the  general  economic
development  or  rehabilitation  of  the  area.  The  Project  will  involve  rehabilitating  the  Sovhoz  2
substation.

D.

Screening of Potential Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures

1.

Potential Environmental Impacts

The  Project  consists  of  rehabilitating  existing  structures.  The  rehabilitation  will  be
9.
implemented  by  small-scale,  decentralized  works  (e.g.,  at  all  substations  to  be  improved);  no
large construction site will be operated for project implementation. After completion, the Project

will not have any undesirable environmental impacts. All potential impacts would happen during
construction.

Air  pollution  and  noise  will  result  from  trucks  carrying  materials,  and  from
machinery  (especially  for  the  excavation  at  NHPP  tailrace).  However,  due  to  the
small  size  of  the  works,  their  limited  duration,  the  low  amount  of  materials  to  be
transported,  and  NHPP's  site  being  in  low  populated  areas,  no  impact  requiring
specific mitigation measures will occur.

An estimated 0.5 to 1.0 million cubic meters of material will have to be excavated
and  dumped  from  the  NHPP  tailrace.  The  material  to  be  excavated  does  not
present any environmental risk and consists of rocks and sediments. The material
will  be  dumped  in  an  area  of  about  7 hectares  that  is  unlevel,  uncultivated,
uninhabited,  and  is  close  to  the  construction  site.  This  land  belongs  to  the  local
government  and  Barki  Tajik  has  obtained  the  government's  authorization  to  use
the  excavated  material  to  fill  the  uneven  pockets.  Such  highly  eroded  land  will
benefit from the filling with the fertile soil dredged from the tailrace. After levelling,
some form of natural tree cover may develop as a consequence.

Some of the electromechanical equipment in all substations and switchyards to be
improved  will  have  to  be  replaced,  as  they  are  worn  out  or  obsolete,  with  spare
parts no longer being available. About 500 tons of transformer oil will be replaced.
The  Government  confirmed  that  no  poly-chlorine-biphenyl  is  included  in  the  oil,
and that the removed oil will be filtered and sold or reused as fuel oil.

10.

The Project will have substantial environmental benefits.

Excavating the tailrace channel at NHPP will increase the production of energy by
320 gigawatt-hours  (GWh)  per  year.  This  amount  of  energy  is  equivalent  to  the
electricity  generated  annually  by  a  40  megawatt  (MW)  coal  fired  power  plant,
which would introduce a large amount of air pollution and carbon emission.

Large  sinkholes  have  opened  in  the  NHPP  switchyard,  and  could  result  in  the
collapse  and  dislocation  of  one  or  more  transformers.  A  rupture  of  these
transformers could lead to an oil spill that could contaminate the Vaksh River. This
river is a main source of irrigation water, and such pollution would adversely affect
the irrigation systems. The Project will eliminate this risk.

Improving  electricity  supply  to  the  Khatlon  Region  population  will  not  directly  and
fully  replace  use  of  other  forms  of  energy,  but  will  reduce  pressure  on  other
resources, mainly on fuelwood used for cooking. Reduced pressure on the scarce
remaining forest cover will be an additional environmental benefit of the Project.

2.

Mitigation Measures

The  most  important  environmental  mitigation  measure  in  relation  to  the  Project  will  be
11.
proper  disposal  of  discarded  material,  especially  transformer  oil  that  has  to  be  replaced.
Contractors  will  be  required  to  filter  and  sell  or  reuse  the  remaining  transformer  oil  as  fuel  oil.

Other material, which cannot be recycled, will be deposited in controlled waste deposit sites and
Barki Tajik agreed to take such steps during project implementation.

12.
During  construction  at  any  site,  care  will  have  to  be  taken  to  prevent  contamination  of
soil and water with fuel and lubricants. This can be done through storage of such substances (if
any) in suitable containers away from water, preferably on an impermeable surface to prevent
oil  from  leaching  into  the  ground,  and  by  proper  maintenance  of  machines  and  trucks.  These
are  normal  engineering  procedures  and  detailed  steps  will  be  included  in  contract  and  bid
documents.  Barki  Tajik  will  assure  periodic  site  monitoring  and  supervision  in  order  to  ensure
compliance.

E.

Institutional Requirements and Environmental Monitoring Program

13.
Environmental  impact  assessments  and  environmental  monitoring  in  Tajikistan  is  the
responsibility of the Ministry of Environment (MOEN). MOEN has the human resources required
to carry out its obligations, but lacks funding, which makes it difficult for staff to carry out these
obligations.

14.
Barki Tajik has a small environmental unit and, given the importance of the relationship
between energy and the environment and the pipeline of other energy projects in the country in
future, Barki Tajik agreed to form an environmental and social monitoring unit to support project
implementation  activities.  Two  person-months  of  international  and  four  person-months  of
domestic  consultant  services  will  be  provided  under  the  Project  to  ensure  all  environmental
mitigation  and  monitoring  activities  will  be  carried  as  specified  in  the  IEE.  The  people
responsible for this unit will also be trained in environmental and social monitoring activities. The
project implementation unit (PIU) will carry out proposed mitigation and monitoring measures on
behalf of Barki Tajik. MOEN will continue its supervisory and advisory functions.

Environmental  monitoring  for  the  Project  includes  baseline  surveys,  periodic  visits,
15.
monitoring and supervision of construction sites for contractors' compliance with regulations and
assurance for proper disposal of waste material. The PIU, with support from the environmental
and social monitoring unit within Barki Tajik, will keep MOEN and ADB informed about progress
of environmental monitoring, and will submit review reports every six months.

F.

Findings and Recommendations

The  Project  will  improve  power  supply  in  Tajikistan  (through  improvements  made  at
16.
NHPP) particularly in the south of the country by improving distribution and transmission in 13
districts of Khatlon Region. Adverse environmental impacts of the Project will be very small, and
will be limited  to the construction period. The most important measures to be taken consist of
proper  disposal  of  discarded  material  (replaced  transformers  and  exchanged  transformer  oil).
Adverse impacts can be mitigated through standard engineering and good construction and civil
works  procedures.  No  negative  environmental  impact  will  persist  during  the  operation  phase.
The Project will not involve resettlement or significant land acquisition.

17.
The  Project  will  have  considerable  environmental  benefits,  mainly  through  (i)  reducing
losses  in  energy  production  at  NHPP;  (ii)  eliminating  the  risk  of  transformer  oil  polluting  the
Vaksh River at NHPP; (iii) improving the safety of NHPP's dam; (iv) reducing electricity losses in
the  distribution system in Khatlon Region, and (v) reducing pressure on alternative sources of
energy,  mainly  forest  resources.  In  addition,  the  Project  will  have  considerable  social  benefits
through improving energy supply and thereby general living conditions of the population. In the

 55

Appendix 8, page 5

project area, improved drinking water supplies; better heating for rural schools, hospitals, clinics,
and other public facilities; and induced agricultural and income generating activities will improve
the social welfare significantly. Since all identified adverse environmental impacts are minor and
can  be  mitigated  through  standard  engineering  and  civil  works  practices,  a  detailed
environmental impact assessment is not needed for the Project.

SUMMARY INITIAL SOCIAL ASSESSMENT

A.

Introduction

1.
An initial social assessment (ISA) was undertaken by consultants as part of the technical
assistance  (TA)1  financed  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB).  The  summary  ISA  covers
social  aspects  of  the  Project.  The  Project  has  five  parts  covering  the  central  and  southern
regions of Tajikistan. ADB fact-finding and appraisal missions visited the project area and held
discussions with government agencies, local government representatives, district officers, Barki
Tajik  (the  state  power  company)  representatives,  and  local  residents  from  10  to  25  April  and
14 to 29 August 2000. The summary ISA was prepared by Barki Tajik, the Executing Agency for
the Project, with inputs from consultants and ADB staff.

B.

2.

C.

Description of the Project

The Project consists of five parts (main text, paras. 51-63).

Present Living Conditions of the Population

The  population  of  Tajikistan  was  6.13  million  in  early  2000  and  is  anticipated  to  reach
3.
11 million  in  2025.  The  population  is  highly  concentrated  in  the  lower  lying  areas  with  fertile
land,  while  mountainous  areas  are  thinly  populated.  The  1997  gross  domestic  product  per
capita  was  $178,  about  33  percent  of  its  level  prior  to  independence.  Tajikistan’s  human
development index decreased from 0.63 in 1991 to 0.54 in 1998, with the country ranked 108
out  of  174 countries  surveyed.  Tajikistan  has  a  high  level  of  poverty.  Official  data  shows  that
although  the  nominal  average  monthly  wages,  minimum  wages,  and  minimum  pension  have
been  increasing  relative  to  1995  levels,  they  are  still  lower  than  1992  levels,  and  more
importantly, are significantly lower than the minimum consumption basket. Average monthly per
capita  income  is  only  25.9  percent  of  the  1998  minimum  consumption  basket,  and  average
monthly  wages,  38.9  percent.  Legislated  minimum  wages  and  minimum  pensions  constitute
only 8.5 percent of the 1998 minimum consumption basket.

4.
Initial social examinations confirm the high levels of poverty, particularly in rural areas. In
February 2000 the State Statistical Agency estimated that 83 percent of the total population is
poor, if monthly expenditure of TJR20,000 was used as the poverty line. Formal employment is
low, and where available, consists mostly of civil service employment, where salaries are often
several months in arrears. Collective farms offer seasonal employment with wages of TJR2,000
per  month  in  spring  and  TJR10,000  during  summer.  Households  supplement  their  incomes
through home plots, animal husbandry, and small-scale retail. In most households visited, these
constituted  the  main  source  of  income.  In  some  areas  households  have  been  provided
humanitarian  aid  by  donor  agencies  through  the  local  government,  consisting  of  5  liters  of
cooking oil and/or 10 kilos of flour supplied every 3-6 months. Most income is received during
summer  and  fall,  coinciding  with  harvests,  but  most  expenses  are  incurred  during  winter  and
spring, mainly for heating and clothing.

 57

Appendix 9, page 2

D.

Social Position of Women

5.
The  relative  position  of  women  has  deteriorated  based  on  the  United  Nations
Development  Programme's  gender-related  development  index,  which  fell  from  0.571  to  0.534
from  1995  to  1998.  Women  are  more  likely  to  be  unemployed  than  men,  with  their
unemployment  rates  at  28.8  and  25.3  percent,  respectively.2  Women’s  wages  average  $2  per
month; men’s wages are $6 per month. Women bear most, if not all of the burden of work within
the household and spend an average of 6.3 hours per day of unpaid work (cooking, working on
private  plots,  cleaning,  laundry,  collecting  fuelwood  and  biomass,  etc.)  compared  to  3.3  hours
by men.

6.
The  project  area  includes  Khatlon  Region,  consisting  of  13  districts.  The  whole  region
has been severely affected by war, which damaged infrastructure and forced a large proportion
of  the  population  to  leave  their  homes.  Most  of  the  refugees  have  returned,  and  are  facing
difficult  conditions  as  most  of  their  houses  have  been  destroyed.  The  war  left  an  estimated
26,000  widows  and  55,000  orphans,  and  their  position  is  worse  than  that  of  the  rest  of  the
people.

E.

Screening of Potential Impacts of the Project

Field visits supported the view that provision of electricity will have a substantial impact
7.
on  the  alleviation  of  poverty.  Aside  from  high  economic  costs  of  using  alternative  fuel,  time,
labor,  health,  social,  and  gender  impacts  are  associated  with  scarcity  of  electricity.  Fuelwood
and agricultural biomass gathering takes 15 days for a month’s supply. Cow dung briquettes are
made  one  hour  of  each  day  in  summer,  to  generate  the  required  supply  for  winter.  These
energy sources are primarily gathered and prepared by women and children. The use of these
energy  sources  typically  for  cooking  in  unventilated  rooms  constitutes  a  health  hazard  for
women and children, who spend approximately five hours per day in these cooking rooms. Safe
water  is  unavailable  partly  because  of  lack  of  electricity,  and  pumping  from  reservoirs  and
deepwells  is  restricted.  The  alternatives  for  securing  water  and  storage  are  both  time
consuming, and often result in contaminated water.

The  collective  farm  Sovhoz  2  in  the  Bishkent  District  is  of  particular  importance  as  it
8.
provides  employment  to  10,000  people.  Due  to  lack  of  electricity  supply  to  the  drainage
pumping  station,  the  land  cannot  be  drained  adequately  for  cultivation,  and  2,500 hectares  of
land  is  now  under  saline  water.  Rehabilitation  of  the  associated  substation  (under  Part  A)  will
provide power to the pumping station.

9.
Metering  will  be  an  important  aspect  of  encouraging  energy  conservation  and  will
provide  for  a  fair  system  of  billing  based  on  consumption.  Where  there  are  no  meters,
households  do  not  practice  energy  conservation  because  electricity  tariffs  are  based  on  the
number  of  rooms  per  household.  Although  many  households  have  arrears  for  their  electricity
bills,  during  focus  group  discussions,  they  indicated  a  willingness  to  pay  up  to  double  the
existing rates for reliable electricity supply.

F.

Findings and Recommendations

10.
The Project will not have any adverse or undesirable social impacts. No resettlement is
required,  and  the  Project  will  not  affect  productive  land  or  any  other  assets  of  the  population.
The  Project  will  directly  improve  electricity  supply  to  a  large  number  of  villages,  with  a  high
percentage of returnee population. In addition, the Project will have considerable social benefits
through  improving  the  general  living  conditions  of  the  population.  Such  benefits  include
improved  drinking  water  supplies;  better  heating  for  rural  schools,  hospitals,  clinics,  and  other
public facilities; improved drainage and control of malaria; increased agricultural production; and
induced income generating activities, that will improve the social welfare significantly. Therefore,
the Project will contribute in a substantial way to poverty reduction.

Because  83  percent  of  the  population  live  below  the  national  poverty  line,  lifeline  tariff
11.
support  is  essential  to  subsidize  electricity  payments  of  the  poor.  The  lifeline  tariff  system
provides  150  kilowatt-hours  (kWh)  of  electricity  to  the  poor  without  any  real  increase  of  price.
Other  options  to  maximize  social  impacts  of  the  Project  include  awareness  building  in  energy
use,  safety,  and  energy  conservation.    The  Government  has  agreed  to  undertake  a  public
awareness  program  to  educate  the  public  on  the  need  for  a  rational  tariff  scheme  and  the
importance  of  energy  conservation.  In  the  future,  Barki  Tajik  will  promote  integrated  energy
development programs with community participation and social mobilization, with emphasis on
cleaner  and  alternative  energy  sources.  Current  community  structures  are  conducive  to
community  participation  and  social  mobilization  in  matters  related  to  electricity  provision,  such
as  household  safety  in  use  of  electricity,  tree  planting  for  fuelwood,  and  use  of  alternative
sources of fuel.

12.
During the policy dialogue, Barki Tajik agreed to establish an environmental and social
impact  monitoring  unit  to  work  very  closely  with  the  project  implementation  unit.  This  unit  will
also  carry  out  regular  project  benefit  monitoring  and  evaluation  activities,  including  annual
review reports. Barki Tajik agreed to provide the unit with adequate equipment, office supplies,
training  facilities,  and  staff  resources  throughout  the  project  implementation  period.  Under  the
Project,  two  person-months  of  international  and  four  person-months  of  domestic  consultants
with  expertise  in  social  impact  monitoring  will  be  provided  with  the  project  implementation
consulting services.
