C.

Part A

3.
Part A consists of rehabilitation and power supply improvement to poor areas in Khatlon
Region.  It  comprises  improvement  of  the  power  supply,  strengthening  of  transmission  and
distribution networks, provision of consumer metering, and improvement of living conditions of
about 24,800 households.

4.
The  major  economic  benefits  of  the  component  are  an  improvement  in  the  Central
Hydropower Plant (15 megawatts), rehabilitation of about 100 villages in 13 districts of Khatlon
Region,  rehabilitation  of  district  transmission  and  distribution  system,  and  installation  of
consumer meters. The component’s benefits include (i) avoided energy losses, (ii) reduction in
technical  and  other  energy  losses,  (iii)  increased  energy  sales  due  to  improved  voltage  and
more  reliable  electricity  supply,  (iv)  savings  in  costs  of  operation  and  maintenance,  and  (iv)
enhancement of well-being of households living in these villages.

D.

Part B

E. 

Part C

Part  B  consists  of  rehabilitating  NHPP  and  associated  transmission  to  improve  its
5.
reliability  of  power  supply.  NHPP  supplies  about  80  percent  of  electricity  generation  in  the
country.    This  plant  was  built  in  stages  from  1962  to  1979  and  there  had  been  minimal  or  no
maintenance work carried out on a regular basis. As a result, heavy siltation and deposition of
other  debris  downstream  of  NHPP  effectively  reduced  the  design  head  by  about  six  meters,
causing  substantial  loss  of  electricity  generation.    The  switchyard  is  built  on  ground  that  has
become  unstable  and  this  can  cause  major  problems  if  the  foundations  are  not  rehabilitated.
Failure  of  one  switchyard  could  reduce  power  transmission  for  several  months  causing  major
economic loss.

Part C includes improvement of the reliability of electricity supplied in Dushanbe region,
6.
the  national  capital  district.  This  component  will  cover  rehabilitation  of  two  substations,
relocating the existing transformers to locations outside the city.

The  provision  of  better  transformers  and  modernization  of  distribution  system  in
7.
Dushanbe region will greatly improve economic activities in the national capital region, which is
subject to frequent power shortages under prevailing conditions. These substations are critical
but  are  overloaded,  more  than  30  years  old,  and  at  the  end  of  their  economic  life.  Their
rehabilitation  will  improve  energy  transmission  efficiency,  reduce  energy  losses,  and  improve
workplace safety.

The incremental power output of the Project is valued on the basis of weighted average
of WTP of TJR90.1/kWh ($0.0450/kWh). This is based on (i) an upper bound of TJR422.0/kWh
for  alternative  energy  source  (kerosene)  and  a  lower  bound  of  TJR7.0/kWh  (average  tariff  for
households), and (ii) curve-linear relationship of 0.3. The nonincremental part of the electricity
generation was estimated taking into account the weighted average cost of alternative (present
use) energy sources. Cost data for this estimation was obtained from the participatory poverty
impact analysis conducted during the feasibility study stage (Appendix 12).

H.

Least Cost Analysis

There is no alternative to the Project given the urgent need for improved power output
11.
and fiscal constraints on building new power facilities. The diversity among project components
made such analysis not possible. However, during the feasibility study, the Project was divided
into a large number of subcomponents and a set of potential alternatives, including a do-nothing
option, and their costs were analyzed. For example, NHPP tailrace dredging was compared with
four options: (i) importing an additional 320 gigawatt-hours (GWh), (ii) building a new hydro or
diesel power plant providing 320 GWh, (iii) increasing efficiency of the turbine with new runners,
and (iv) do-nothing. The proposed tailrace dredging is the least cost option. In a similar manner,
least-cost  options  were  examined  for  the  13  subcomponents  of  the  Project,  resulting  in  more
than 25 options. These analyses confirmed that all project components are a part of the least-
cost plan for power subsector development in the country.

SUMMARY POVERTY IMPACT ANALYSIS

A.

Introduction

The  poverty  reduction  impact  of  the  Project  was  assessed  during  project  preparation.1
1.
Six  household-based  focus  groups,  three  village-based  workshops,  four  discussions  with
interest groups, and a national-level consultative meeting with stakeholders were conducted in
the project area. Participatory development exercises were held to understand the quality and
accessibility  of  electricity  and  determine  its  linkages  with  levels  of  poverty  in  the  project  area.
The Project has five parts (paras. 51-63 of the main report).

B.

Poverty in Tajikistan

2.
Tajikistan  is  composed  of  four  geographical  regions:  Gorno-Badakhshan,  Khatlon,
Lenninabad,  and  Region  of  Republican  Subordination.  Although  the  country  was  the  poorest
republic  in  the  former  Soviet  Union,  investment  in  social  infrastructure  through  large  budget
transfers  from  Moscow,  equivalent  to  40  percent  of  gross  domestic  product,  helped  sustain
social and economic infrastructure. Tajikistan inherited high levels of human capital which have
not  been  sustained  after  independence,  when  the  absence  of  budget  transfers,  collapse  of
interrepublican  trading,  poor  economic  management  until  mid-1990s,  civil  conflict,  and  major
natural disasters led to a decline in living conditions.

Tajikistan  is  experiencing  high  levels  of  poverty.  A  World  Bank  study2  reports  that
3.
approximately 83 percent of the population are poor, and have insufficient resources to cover all
basic  needs  of  food,  shelter,  clothing,  education,  and  health  despite  supplementary  income.
Some of the poverty is cyclical, with shortages of fuel during winter and food during spring. Of
this  group,  roughly  5  percent  are  classified  as  destitute,  and  unable  to  care  for  themselves
(including  the  aged,  orphans  and  street  children,  disabled,  and  unemployed);  and  12  percent
are experiencing extreme poverty, facing chronic food insecurity or malnutrition with no regular
or dependable source of income.

Although the nominal average monthly wages, minimum wages, and minimum pension
4.
has been increasing relative to 1995 levels, they are substantially lower than 1992 levels, and
more  importantly,  are  significantly  lower  than  the  cost  of  the  minimum  consumption  basket.
Average  monthly  per  capita  income  is  only  25.9  percent  of  the  1998  minimum  consumption
basket; average monthly wages, 38.9 percent. Legislated minimum wage and minimum pension
constitute only 8.5 percent of the 1998 minimum consumption basket.

Based  on  income  and  expenditure  patterns  of  households,3  the  national  minimum
5.
consumption basket in 1998 was equivalent to TJR18,399. Since there is no regional minimum
consumption  basket  for  Khatlon  Region,  if  TJR15,000  was  used  as  the  poverty  line,  at  least
80.2 percent of the population is poor based on their incomes. Using expenditure patterns, the
percentage  of  poor  individuals  is  slightly  higher  at  81.4  percent.  Rural  poverty  based  on  the
minimum consumption basket is lower than urban poverty based on income at 79.3 percent and
85.5 percent, respectively; and slightly higher based on expenditures at 81.3 percent and 81.1
percent, respectively.
                                                          
1 TA  5894-REG:  Facilitating  Capacity  Building  and  Participatory  Activities  II,  for  $400,000,  approved  on

28 December 1999.

2  Falkingham, J. 1999. Women and Gender Relations in Tajikistan. London School of Economics, London.
3  United Nations Development Programme's and World Bank's Tajikistan Living Standards Survey, May 1999.

 67

Appendix 12, page 2

C.

Potential Poverty Reduction Impacts

6.
Participatory  development  exercises  confirm  high  levels  of  poverty,  particularly  in  rural
areas.  Formal  employment  is  low,  and  where  available,  consists  mostly  of  civil  service
employment  where  salaries  are  often  several  months  in  arrears;  or  seasonal  employment  in
collective  farms  paying  TJR2,000  per  month  during  spring  and  TJR10,000  during  summer.
Women have lower levels of formal employment than men. Women spend more time at home
doing unpaid work. Households supplement their incomes through working on home plots, milk
production,  livestock,  and  small-scale  retail.  In  most  households  visited,  these  constituted  the
main  source  of  income.  Poor  households  receive  from  donor  agencies  through  the  local
government humanitarian aid consisting of 5 liters of cooking oil and/or 10 kilos of flour supplied
every 3-6 months. Most income is received during summer and fall, coinciding with harvests, but
most expenses are incurred during winter and spring, mainly for heating and clothing.

7.
Before  independence  in  1991,  electricity  supply  had  been  reliable.  But  since  then,  the
provision of electricity has deteriorated sharply. Households confirm that electricity is available
intermittently for most of the year except during the winter months (December to March) when
electricity  is  only  available  for  2-4  hours  a  day.  Because  of  lack  of  electricity,  people  have
increased  their  reliance  on  alternative  sources  of  fuel.  The  most  typical  alternatives  are
fuelwood,  agricultural  waste,  animal  dung,  and  diesel.  Three  to  five  cubic  meters  of  fuelwood
and  agricultural  waste  are  required  per  month  during  winter,  and  1-2  cubic  meters  during
summer months. At a market value of TJR5,000 per cubic meter, households spend as much as
TJR25,000  (including  time  and  cost)  on  fuel  during  winter  months.  Where  fuelwood  is  scarce,
animal dung is used intensively, averaging 1,500 briquettes per household during winter months
and 300 briquettes during rest of the year, valued at TJR15,000 mainly for labor cost. Diesel is
primarily  used  for  lighting  and  igniting  fuelwood  or  animal  dung.  Interviews  with  some
households  show  that  the  cost  for  using  diesel  for  illumination  can  reach  TJR18,000  during
winter when electricity is not available. Other alternatives such as kerosene, coal, and liquefied
petroleum gas, though available, are used in limited quantities due to prohibitive costs. Further,
the sources of these fuels are typically several kilometers from villages, and households do not
store these fuels due to indoor safety considerations.

8.
Field visits supported the view that the provision of electricity will have substantial impact
on reduction of poverty and improving the living conditions of the poor. In Tajikistan, as in other
Central  Asian  countries,  electricity  provision  has  clear  links  with  the  level  of  poverty.  Due  to
harsh winters, heat is a basic need. For three decades the Tajik people had reliable, year-round
electricity, but are now often deprived of it.

9.
Alternative  fuels  are  expensive  and  entail  high  costs  in  time,  labor,  health,  social  and
gender  impacts.  Fuelwood,  agricultural  waste,  and  biomass  gathering  takes  15  days  for  one
month of use. Households spend one hour daily each summer making cow dung briquettes to
generate the required supply for winter. Gathering and preparing these energy sources is done
primarily  by  women  and  children.  The  use  of  these  energy  sources,  typically  for  cooking  in
unventilated  rooms,  is  a  health  hazard  for  women  and  children  who  spend  approximately  five
hours  per  day  in  these  cooking  rooms.  During  focus  group  discussions,  participants  ranked
electricity  as  the  best  form  of  energy  based  on  availability,  convenience,  affordability,  time,
indoor safety, environmental considerations, and storage requirements. This is often followed by
fuelwood, agricultural wastes, animal dung, and diesel.

 68

Appendix 12, page 3

Households identified the lack of food, clothing, shelter, water, and employment as the
10.
main  issues  concerning  poverty,  and  recognized  that  energy  is  an  important  element  in  the
provision  of  basic  needs.  In  the  areas  visited,  safe  water  is  unavailable  partly  because  of  the
lack  of  electricity.  Prior  to  independence,  piped  water  had  been  provided  to  households.
However,  due  to  the  irregular  and  inadequate  electricity  supply,  pumping  from  reservoirs  and
deepwells  has  been  restricted.  The  people  have  coped  by  obtaining  water  from  rivers  and
reservoirs  using  donkeys  and  trolleys,  and  may  have  to  travel  up  to  15  kilometers  to  such
sources. Due to transportation and storage, water obtained is often contaminated. Community
organizations  have  developed  open  water  pools  made  of  compacted  clay  to  store  water
delivered  by  trucks  for  local  consumption.  However,  the  pools  are  exposed  to  contamination,
making their water unsuitable for drinking. This water is often not boiled due to the scarcity of
electricity.

11.
On  the  issue  of  employment,  the  large  agricultural  base,  which  depends  on  irrigation,
has suffered from the unavailability of pumped irrigation. As a result, the yield has dropped to
20-25  percent  of  former  levels.  In  one  village,  2,500  hectares  of  productive  fields  that  once
employed  10,000  individuals  have  become  flooded.  The  flood  water  is  saline,  and  this  has
contaminated the groundwater. Malaria is also common in the area. In areas where the problem
is  not  as  severe,  pumping  and  drainage  facilities  often  break  down,  and  irrigation  is  available
only irregularly.

12.
The  provision  of  education  and  health  services  to  the  population  is  similarly  hampered
by the lack of electricity. Since electricity is available in rural areas for only up to two hours daily
during  winter,  schools  do  not  receive  adequate  electricity  for  heating  and  lighting.  They  have
tried  alternative  forms  of  energy,  such  generators,  but  these  have  not  been  widely  adopted
because  of  the  high  cost  involved.  In  some  areas,  children  are  asked  to  bring  a  bundle  of
fuelwood  or  agricultural  waste  to  fuel  indoor  stoves.  Because  heating  is  often  not  available,
schools are typically closed for two months during winter, and operate for extended hours during
summer, which has negative psychological effects on students. School enrolment has dropped,
particularly since poor children may lack warm clothes and shoes, and therefore do not attend
school during the rest of winter. Hospitals also lack heating. In winter, surgical operations can
only be  performed during the  few hours when electricity is available. This affects the ability to
respond  to  emergency  medical  situations  and  forces  hospitals  to  prioritize  cases  accordingly.
Medicines  and  vaccines  cannot  be  properly  stored  at  controlled  conditions  due  to  the  lack  of
electricity. As a consequence, many hospitals have been closed and those that are open are at
the administrative centers. This results in high transportation costs and travel time for patients,
leading to even higher expenses for the poor who do not live near the centers.

13.
Households  identified  employment  and  small  entrepreneurial  activities  they  could
undertake if electricity were available. Households invest considerable time collecting alternative
fuel  (such  as  fuelwood,  agricultural  waste  or  cow  dung).  This  prevents  women  from  greater
participation  in  the  labor  force  and  limits  productive  home  activities  such  as  working  on  home
plots.  If  more  electricity  were  available,  households  would    (i)  increase  their  entrepreneurial
activities  such  as  grain  milling,  baking,  sewing,  small-scale  and  trade  activities;  (ii)  have
increased  information  from  mass  media;  and  (iii)  have  greater  convenience  from  use  of  light
bulbs  and  small  household  appliances.  Electricity  is  also  necessary  for  encouraging  private
investments.

 69

Appendix 12, page 4

D. 

Benefit Distribution and Poverty Impact Analysis

14.
The difference between the financial and economic net present values, and consequent
gains and losses for different project participants, provide the basis for considering the impact of
the Project on the poor. For the poverty impact assessment, the project beneficiaries are divided
into three groups: consumers, Government economy, and labor. The net economic benefits by
group are distributed between poor and nonpoor.

The principal economic benefit of the Project to the consumers will arise from increasing
15.
the  power  supply  to  meet  incremental  electricity  demand,  particularly  in  war  damaged  areas.
The  incremental  electricity  in  the  project  area  will  benefit  the  poor  more  than  the  nonpoor  as
their  consumption  is  projected  to  increase  faster  because  of  (i)  their  current  lower  electricity
consumption  level,    (ii)  the  lower  electricity  tariffs  compared  to  alternative  energy  costs,  and
(iii) more connections due to the Project. The consumers will also benefit from rehabilitation of
Nurek  Hydropower  Plant,  as  it  is  the  least-cost  option.  Based  on  the  Project's  share  of  poor
consumers,  their  electricity  consumption  pattern,  and  the  number  of  people  living  below  the
poverty  line,  59  percent  of  the  benefits  to  consumers  would  go  to  the  poor.  This  is  a
conservative  estimate  given  that  indirect  benefits  from  industrial  consumption  and  all  other
sources  have  not  been  fully  taken  into  account  and  are  likely  to  benefit  the  poor  more  than
others. In Tajikistan, 83 percent of the population live below official poverty line. Staff estimated4
that 76 percent of the return to the Government benefits the poor. Similarly, 70 percent of the
labor benefits are expected to go to the poor.

16.
The  increased,  more  efficient,  and  more  reliable  electricity  supply  resulting  from  the
Project  will  benefit  the  poor  directly  and  indirectly  (Table  A12).  The  net  economic  benefits
accruing to the poor amount to $27 million. Thus, 57 percent of the net economic benefits of the
Project  will  accrue  to  the  poor  (i.e.,  the  poverty  impact  ratio  is  57  percent).  Some  indirect
economic  and  social  benefits  were  not  captured  in  this  analysis.  If  these  benefits  were  also
considered, it is expected that a substantial portion of the project benefits will go to the poor, in
support of the Project's primary objective of poverty reduction.

E.

Conclusions

17.
The  Project  will  help  reduce  poverty,  and  its  poverty  impact  ratio  is  57  percent.  The
project area is characterized by high levels of poverty and is largely rural. Electricity is a basic
need in the project area for heat, cooking, and pumping of safe drinking water. The Project will
also support the improvement of essential services such as water for irrigation, education, and
health.  It  will  provide  direct  employment,  and  make  the  environment  conducive  for  generating
more  jobs  through  (i)  economic  development  as  a  direct  input  of  production,  and  (ii)  reducing
the  time  spent  on  using  energy  alternatives  for  more  productive  activities.  This  will  have
significant impact on vulnerable groups, particularly women and children.

 71

Appendix 13, page 1

IMPACT OF TARIFF INCREASES ON THE POOR IN TAJIKISTAN

A. 

Introduction

Electricity tariffs have to be increased over the coming years to full cost recovery (FCR)
1.
of electricity supply, to ensure the financial sustainability of Barki Tajik. However, the increase in
tariff  is  especially  difficult  for  the  poor  to  bear,  particularly  households  headed  by  women,
households  with  the  elderly  people,  and  rural  households  with  many  children.  Therefore,  a
mechanism is needed to safeguard the poor from the effects of increased electricity tariff.

B.

3.
The  TA  concluded  that  the  first  option  is  not  viable  as  it  does  not  have  a  social  safety
component. Other than the lifeline tariff initiated in 1999, Tajikistan currently has no functioning
safety net. If residential tariffs were raised to FCR as per option 1, this would be a 500 percent
increase in tariff to the poor, who would be spending 8.3 percent of their incomes on electricity
compared to current expenditures of 1.8 percent.2 Options 2 and 3 pose difficulties, namely: (i)
the  definition  of  the  poverty  line  (the  "poorest  20  percent"  is  an  arbitrary  line  without  any
objective  poverty  criteria);  (ii)  the  identification  of  households  entitled  for  lifeline  subsidy,  as
many people who would be entitled for nonemployment payment or other social security are not
registered,  partly  because  the  procedures  involved  are  cumbersome  and  costs  are  high;  and

 72

Appendix 13, page 2

(iii)  the  actual  disbursement  of  the  lifeline  subsidy.  Option  4  overcomes  these  problems  but
treats  all  households  equally.  However,  as  83  percent  of  the  population  is  poor,  it  is  not
absolutely  devoid  of  targeting,  since  only  the  first  150  kWh  is  subsidized.  Option  5  is  a
refinement  of  option  4  and  is  not  feasible  with  the  present  economic  situation  as  it  requires  a
significant  number  of  households  consuming  over  300  kWh  per  month  to  provide  the  cross-
subsidy.

4.
Option 4 represents the status quo up to a consumption level of 150 kWh per month as a
lifeline tariff, with increases in tariff up to FCR for consumption beyond 150 kWh. Based on data
of  Falkingham3 and the World  Bank survey,4  and  on  the  assumption  that  150  kWh  as  a  basic
supply  to  be  subsidized,  the  findings  of  this  analysis  show  that  the  poorest  20  percent  of
households,  under  present  conditions,  pay  3  percent  of  their  monthly  income  for  electricity.
Income  as  defined  includes  the  monetized  contribution  of  their  subsistence  production,  as
83 percent of the population are poor.  Since salaries make up only a part of the total income,
the electricity bill consumes a larger percentage of their actual cash income.

C.

Estimation of Cost of Lifeline Subsidy

Lifeline subsidy for electricity supply of households involves costs, which will have to be
5.
paid by the Government to Barki Tajik. Based on certain assumptions, the financial cost of the
lifeline tariff subsidy was estimated. Table A13 highlights these costs, which are based on the
following assumptions. The present level of lifeline tariff is $0.0025/kWh and this is adjusted for
inflation  only.  The  present  level  of  electricity  consumption  is  about  80  kWh  per  month  per
household  and  this  is  not  expected  to  increase  without  the  Project.  This  is  a  reasonable
assumption  as  electricity  supply  will  deteriorate  without  the  Project.  Poor  households  require
about 150 kWh of electricity per month for basic needs. This includes lighting, heating (during
winter only), and cooking for four hours per day.

6.
The analysis shows the subsidy per year by the Government to fund the lifeline tariff will
rise from 2004 (about $0.6 million) to 2008 (about $4.0 million). As the Government proposes to
use  the  interest  margin  arising  from  relending  of  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  loan  and
cofinancier  (Swiss  Government)  proceeds  to  fund  subsidies  to  Barki  Tajik  for  the  lifeline  tariff,
the net subsidy per year from Government budget in 2004 is expected to be about $0.6 million,5
which rises to $2.1 million in 2008. Hence, during 2004 to 2008, a cumulative subsidy of about
$6.3 million is required from the Government budget. On average this is equivalent annually to
about 1 percent of the current annual Government budget. The Government has agreed that it
will take necessary measures to make up for any shortfall in the subsidy to Barki Tajik arising
from the implementation of the lifeline tariff.

D.

Conclusion

Inclusion  of  all  households  in  the  lifeline  subsidy  is  justified  because  83  percent  of  the
7.
population  are  poor,  and  eliminates  the  administrative  problem  of  targeting  and  delivering  to
those entitled to the subsidy. The present lifeline tariff of TJR5/kWh is considered acceptable for
poor  households.  After  the  power  supply  improves,  the  lifeline  subsidy  is  to  be  reviewed  and

                                                          
3  Falkingham, J. 1999. Women and Gender Relations in Tajikistan. London: London School of Economics.
4 World Bank. June 2000. Tajikistan Poverty Assessment. Washington, DC.
5 No reduction in subsidy because of 5-year grace period on relending to Barki Tajik.

 73

Appendix 13, page 3

tariff is to be increased gradually, provided the economic situation of the population improves at
a rate to allow for this. The aim should be to ultimately eliminate the lifeline subsidy by a gradual
rise of the tariff until this reaches FCR.

8.

The Government in principle has agreed to:

(i) 

(ii) 

maintain  the  current  lifeline  tariff  (in  real  terms)  and  level  until  the  national
poverty  reduction  strategy,  which  is  to  be  finalized  in  mid-2001,  is  implemented
(among the proposals to be considered include a cash compensation scheme for
the poor and vulnerable groups, and the gradual introduction of a three-tier tariff
for residential consumers);

discuss  with  the  national  Poverty  Reduction  Working  Group  and  develop  a
proposal for a satisfactory safety net for the poor and vulnerable groups affected
by  electricity  tariff  increases;  proposals  must  be  acceptable  to  ADB  and
submitted by January 2002 as per the Energy Sector Action Plan; and

(iii) 

hold a public awareness program from January 2001 to educate the public on the
need for a rational tariff scheme and the importance of energy conservation.
